response.answer_text: Biochemistry is hard, because it assumes you know a lot of relatively knew knowledge. Take math for example. When you take calculus, it assumes you know algebra and some trig. You have been taking algebra and trig for years, so it’s old topics with new applications and twists. Biochem is different. Biochem uses organic chemistry, a class you take in college. Hell you might take biochem right after it. Biochem uses cellular and molecular biology. A class you also take in college. Biochem uses physics, a class you take in college. I assume you see the trend here. You are now using 3–4 different concepts that you just learned a few months ago or a year or 2 ago. This isn’t a course where you have been training or doing it for years (chem in high school won’t help you at all, and most people don’t even take physics in high school), it’s a course where it assumes you’ve completely understood the previous courses you’ve recently taken, and now wants you to apply it. This is what makes biochem harder than other subjects.

I don’t think so and I majored in it (chem side) I just wasn’t passionate about the subject and something my parents wanted me to do (premed). So I’m comparing to learning how to trade, computer programming, data science. It’s very doable and I think easier than all the above. Ochem is just putting a puzzle together with memorized reactions. There will be a lot of memorization. Kreb cycle. Citric acid cycle. The math is not complicated at all. Frankly it’s all about internalizing info and then fitting it together to come up with something cohesive. I guess one could say the same about the endeavors mentioned above, but all are less straightforward and more about adapting to the current circumstances and project, not as much information on these subjects (exception programming, where everything is known). Perhaps cutting edge biochemistry is a bit different, but then it really requires you know how different proteins and kinases operate, etc etc. A lot of memorization so you know the lay of the land and can make educated guesses about what research to conduct. If you’re doing bench work as a technician. It’s basically following a fancy cookbook recipe unless you’re really doing cutting edge things…and even that is just trial and error based on what has worked for other things in the past. Time consuming, yes. Particularly difficult, no IMHO.

BOTH At times, it is hard. Like mind frustrating, exasperating, angering, mind bogglingly and annoyingly hard. You will feel like to give up. Some nights, tons of coffee won’t help you either. Remembering those amino acids, carbohydrates, lipids, wont be easy at all. Confusion will be a constant partner. Trying to imagine those micro , nano substances will be hard. Coping with the pressure of all those things will be difficult. Teachers wont always explain you in detail. Searching 3–4 huge books and sometimes even more will be time consuming as well as tiring. But at the end of the day(or night) , being able to solve that single question, understanding the entire topic and being able to connect all those small things ,will be worth it. Yes biochemistry is a practical subject, it will demand a lot of your time in its practicals but to be able to do practicals you need the knowledge , you need to study. Personally, for me biochemistry is like a mystery, u solve one and it gives you a clue for the next. Even though it is hard at times, it will never be boring. If you put your effort,it will be hard in the starting but latter on , it pays, it will be easy.!!

It is not hard. Same difficulty as general biology. Often it is more interesting to the student than chemistry (more biology, which is familiar and observable) but more sophisticated than intro biology. If you passed biology and chemistry you can pass fundamentals of biochemistry (biochemistry 101). Anyone can if told the facts. Same amount of info as biology…. If you bombed organic chemistry totally or haven’t taken it that will not hinder you in biochemistry one bit. Most biochemists don’t understand organic chemistry at all. It’s not necessary. You do not run biochemistry reactions. Only the body can do that. You measure but don’t manipulate things much, you separate things but only to know mass…not to move it forward. …you hope that your research is practical. You never know. It takes a life of work to maybe discover something useful in biochemistry. In chemistry, it happens in months. The work is tougher, more mentally challenging and way more fun. I learned it in reverse as it was my major. Knowing functional group name made no difference. Just understand polarity.

How difficult your study of biochemistry will turn out depends on the following factors. Do you know and understand organic chemistry well?Which textbook do you choose?Does the teacher force you to memorize the long chains of reactions?Regarding the tutorial, I highly recommend the book by Jeremy M. Berg and John L. Tymoczko. You can use their short or full course. Stay away from the Lehninger Principles of Biochemistry. In organic chemistry, the best textbook is currently the manual by David R. Klein. In my opinion, this book is fascinating, and not just detailed. If you master its material, you will become a life sciences superstar. Unfortunately, you cannot influence your biochemistry teacher’s approach to presenting material and evaluating student performance. The curriculum of the biochemistry and molecular biology courses overlap to a large extent. After passing biochemistry, it will be much easier for you in subsequent years of study.

It's not exceedingly difficult. It's mostly just memorization on top of memorization on top of even more memorization. If you're referring to how hard biochem is as a subject to pass, it really isn't that hard as long as you have the drive to read. However, if you're referring to how hard it is as a scientific field (research), the difficulty stems from the fact that biochemical systems are mind-bogglingly complex. There are simply too many variables that need to be controlled. Biochemical systems are chaotic such that a small change in your starting conditions can yield to massive deviations over time.

Learning Biochemistry is like breaking a Magician's code. At first it all seems like mission impossible. Very mysterious, looks crazy, like get-outta-here kind of amusement!! But slowly and carefully when you unravel the mystery step by step… it all comes together like a beautiful story. You have clarity about what exactly happens within you. It is still so magical that our body has the capacity to do all of those things at such a miniscule level, so well managed and economical…!! You will know what I mean when you get into the subject. So… BIOCHEMISTRY is not a subject, it's a treasure map! Go explore and have fun doing so!

If you mean how dificult is it to master the fundamentals of the subject, it depends on your background.  I would say a strong grounding in general and organic chemistry is essential, and some introductory molecular biology is helpful.  Biochemistry seems overwhelmingly complicated at the begining, but later on in your studies, the interlinking of various metabolic pathways makes the overall picture emerge.  It's a bit like a jigsaw puzzle, you need quite a few pieces in place before the overall picture is seen, and then the details are a lot easier to navigate.

No, Biochemistry is not hard. It is simply the Chemistry of life . Remember, I have been telling that life is a system of co- operative enzyme catalysed reactions. Understanding the basis of life processes in terms of molecular reactions is Biochemistry. If you have the basics in chemistry you understand Biochemistry easily & you will be able to appreciate the subject. Again remember Biochemistry forms the basis of all life sciences including clinical sciences. Is it not interesting to understand the physiological basis of normal/ pathological processes in molecular terms. You only need to apply your mind to love the subject. Good luck

How smart are you? I can only give a comparative answer, relating the “degree of difficulty” to other areas of study. Compared to any non- science major it is hard - as are all science and math degrees. Compared to other science degrees it will depend on your own abilities and interests. If you are excellent in math you might want to try physics. This not to say that math is unimportant but that the field is less math intensive than physics or engineering. However, compared to zoology there is a lot of math involved. Keep in mind the chemistry aspect. Lastly, it is a complex field and will absorb whatever degree of effort you apply to it.

It's hard because 1.its too much of imagination. 2.The molecule from one metabolism comes to visit the other metabolism,then this visiting molecule becomes very important. 3.We study it in compartments,though it's all really mixed up. 4.What is taught is actually of no use practically. as laboratory and diagnostic demands your other skills. 5.And after struggling to learn everything,you realize that you have forgotten everything as it's the most volatile subject.Imagining doesn't help much in this

I do not think so, as it was not hard for me. Mentally, there are courses in college that are well known as the hard course that washes out majors in those fields, I do not think biochemistry is one of those topics. Organic and physical chemistry, comparative anatomy, are such subjects in my experience. Maybe I should elaborate. To do well in any endeavor one needs to work hard to become competent in the area. There are concepts that may be difficult for some to learn, and these are different for different people. For example, I have a very good friend that though physical chemistry was easy and it was very difficult for me, but he had lots of issues with biochemistry.

Biochemistry is not tough at all. It's the most easy biology subject. In this you study about the biomolecules. Biomolecules are the building blocks of biological world. Studying about them is very interesting. You know about how our body is made of, how it performs so many complex functions. What is DNA how it stores and transfer the information. These are few little things as you will study it you will came to know about many other more interesting things.

I have a brother who worked this field as a professor of microbiology. He had a project that took 20 years to complete. As I listened to him talk about it over the years, I noticed in the thick of things he felt the material as complicated. However, when he finally completed an x-ray crystallography model of the biochemistry he worked on, he spoke of it in the simplest of terms.

hello there, Biochemistry is not hard. It requires more dedication and more will to study and to understand the details of all of the chemical processes and reactions occuring inside our body. The subject is itself very vast and it requires excess efforts than other subjects to get a grip on it. But once you are able to do that, You surely will be at a very good pace and you will not find the subject difficult at all. Hope this helps, Good luck.

Its not at all hard if you understand it properly and follow good books, for example Lehninger. Though memorising reactions become tough at some point of time, especially the 1000s of structures, but practice again and again and you will find it very easy. Just keep your concepts clear from the starting and everything else will fall into place. It is one of the most interesting subjects I have studied.

Yes it is and Biochem has some odd features. It seems to be a subject like Chinese where you cannot learn it from a book, you have to be taught. The rote learning is very heavy which means that a lot of students that do pass biochem do not actually have any real understanding. Also Biochem is more a subject for a chemist interested in biology than a biologist with some interest in chemistry. The chemistry demands of Biochem are very high.

If it were easy, everyone would be doing it. That being said, it isn’t particularly difficult as long as you have a solid grasp on the prerequisite material, are willing to put in the study time, and are reasonably comfortable dealing with systems.

Frankly speaking I am afraid too from Chemistry. But when I was started learning biochemistry I found it is more interesting. Like a treasure hunting, and you will have curiosity constantly. The important factor is your interest to know the things and in the subject. I believe biochemistry is a wonderful stream of science. Though sincere efforts make it easy. Go ahead if it's your 1st choice of study.
THAT critically depends on how much work you put into it. The harder you work, the harder it gets. Same as any other specialty.
Easy, I love this paper.
NO it's not to hard if u study well then it is very easy
